sentences: Neil Nongkynrih (9 July 1970 – 5 January 2022) was an Indian concert pianist and conductor.
He founded the Shillong Chamber Choir (SCC), which won the reality show India's Got Talent in 2010.
He was awarded Padma Shri, the fourth highest civilian award of India in 2015.

Nongkynrih was born in Jaiaw Langsning, Khasi Hills district, in the then state of Assam (now East Khasi Hills district, Meghalaya state) to A. H. Scott Lyngdoh, a former state minister of Meghalaya, and Elvirial Nongkynrih.
In 1988, against his father's wishes, he moved to the United Kingdom to study music.
He returned to India in 2001 and started teaching piano in Shillong.
In the same year, he founded the Shillong Chamber Choir (SCC).
Nongkynrih came back home to Shillong in India in 2001 after fourteen years in Europe leaving behind a potential career as a classical pianist there.
Nongkynrih came back home to Shillong in India in 2001 after fourteen years in Europe leaving behind a potential career as a classical pianist there.
In a later interview he referred to the violence in the region and said he had heard the sounds of the guns early in 2001 and decided that he wanted to replace it with the sound of music.

The choir shot to national fame after it won the reality talent show, India's Got Talent (Season 2) in October 2010, on Colors TV, part of the Got Talent franchise, where it performed western chorals, as well as choral-style revamps of Hindi film (Bollywood) classics.
Under Nongkynrih's direction, the choir participated in the 6th World Choir Games held at Shaoxing China (Shanghai) in July 2010 and was awarded Gold in all three categories viz.
The choir also performed for Barack Obama and Michelle Obama, the US President and first lady at the time, during their visit to India in 2010.
Over the years, Nongkynrih worked on revamping the Choir's repertoire with many new compositions and out of the box medleys apart from the opera Sohlyngngem that he was working on.
A collaboration with Zakir Hussain, Usha Uthup and Shankar–Ehsaan–Loy led to a best-selling Christmas music album in 2011.
A collaboration with Zakir Hussain, Usha Uthup and Shankar–Ehsaan–Loy led to a best-selling Christmas music album in 2011.
Performances at the Gateway of India in remembrance of the 26/11 terror attacks in 2012 & 2013.
Performances at the Gateway of India in remembrance of the 26/11 terror attacks in 2012 & 2013.
Nongkynrih was made a member of the board of India's Central Board of Film Certification (CBFC) in 2017.
section: == Career == | ==== Central Board of Film Certification ====

sentences: Earlier, in 2012, Nongkynrih was appointed by the World Choir Council for a four-year term on the council.

Even though excerpts from the opera have been performed earlier, three pieces from the opera were performed by the SCC at the MTV India Music Summit in 2019, held in Jaipur which was a highlight of the three-day musical event.
The school was later named the Shillong Chamber School and had about 20 students in attendance as of 2016.
section: == Career == | ==== Home school – Shillong Chamber School ====

sentences: The students of the school have performed with the SCC and the European Concert Orchestra in Mumbai for a Christmas Concert and also before Rajiv Bajaj and cricketer MS Dhoni at a private event in Pune.

sentences: Nongkynrih was awarded the Padma Shri (the fourth highest civilian award of India) in 2015 for his contribution in the field of arts through his music.
Honorary doctorate for his contributions in the field of music, NIT Meghalaya, 2021
Padma Shri, 2015
U Tirot Sing Award, 2011
Forbes Person of the Year, 2010–11
Member, Central Board of Film Certification, India, 2017–2022
Nongkynrih died at a hospital in Mumbai on 5 January 2022, at the age of 51.
